contentrichtext.text: {{no footnotes|date=March 2008}} '''Dragan Marušič''' (born 1953) is a [[Slovenes|Slovene]] [[mathematician]]. His research focuses on topics in [[algebraic graph theory]], particularly the [[symmetry]] of [[graph theory|graph]]s and the action of [[finite group]]s on combinatorial objects. In 2002, he helped show that the [[Gray graph]] is the smallest cubic [[semi-symmetric graph]], resolving a long-open problem. From 1968 to 1972 Marušič attended [[gymnasium (school)|gymnasium]] in [[Koper]]. He studied undergraduate mathematics at the [[University of Ljubljana]]. He completed his Ph.D. at the [[University of Reading]] under the supervision of [[Crispin Nash-Williams]]. Marušič is regarded as the founder of the Slovenian school of research in [[algebraic graph theory]] and [[permutation group]]s.{{citation needed|date=December 2009}} Currently, he is the third [[Rector (academia)|rector]] of the [[University of Primorska]]. In 2002 he received the [[Žiga Zois|Zois award]] for his achievements in the field of [[graph theory]] and [[algebra]]; founding editor of the ''[[Ars Mathematica Contemporanea]]''. ==External links== *{{MathGenealogy|id=37105}} * [http://draganmarusic.si personal web page] ==References== {{reflist}} *{{cite journal | author=Malnič, A.; Marušič, D.; Potočnik, P.; and Wang, C. | title=An Infinite Family of Cubic Edge-Transitive but Not Vertex-Transitive Graphs | journal=Discr.
